expiration or basically a day or two before somewhere in that near to expiration time period say that the stock goes up to $91 and you're upset you're basically saying hey I don't want to lose these shares yet because my cost basis is 100 I did sell a 90 covered call let's say it was for a doll so technically you're breaking even at 91 but say you don't want to get rid of the shares what you can do then is actually roll that covered call higher so you can take that 90 covered call and close that 90 and then open up a 95 and in most cases if you do that far out enough you can still collect a credit or at least Break Even but even if you break even now at least you don't have to get rid of the stock at 90 you can get get rid of it at 955 now let's talk about the call side if a call goes into the money what will happen is you will get exercised and lose your shares in the wheel strategy right so you first of all can get assigned on the puts you have to buy stock but if you get assigned on the calls you have to sell stock so say you don't want to sell your shares what you can do again is roll and close out that position what is likely to happen most of the time is that someone will actually end up selling covered calls that are out of the money and it's perfect perfectly fine because as long as it's out of the money you're going to be collecting premium if it's in the money then you're going to lose your stock if you wait until Friday expiration or you can roll it out higher there's two things that you can basically do if you get assigned so be it if it's above your cost basis you're probably happy if you don't want to lose your shares and you are at a gain that's okay too again you can roll now one important thing that I just want to say with the wheel strategy something that people do not realize is no matter which way in which direction it's going you can still dollar cost average and sell more put options or sell more covered calls by buying more shares especially if it is below your strike price especially if it is below your cost basis so for example let's say that a stock is at 100 okay you end up selling a 90 put option okay it goes down to 95 that doesn't mean that you can't sell more put options at 90 let's say it goes down to 85 you can still sell more put options at 80 so you can continuously sell more put options the entire life cycle of running the wheel strategy and that would be dollar cost averaging the wheel strategy there's nothing wrong with that the only issue is say you have $30,000 and you put $155,000 into Apple well you can't really dollar cost more into Apple because it's already 50% of your portfolio so when you are dollar cost averaging into the wheel strategy you want to make sure that you have 5 10 15% of your entire money in a single position therefore if it does does go down you can do more of the wheel strategy on the same stock dollar cost averaging but not exceeding like 30 or 40% of your portfolio the less of your portfolio you have in one single position the better the more Diversified you are

excerpt: A put option gives the holder the right but not the obligation to sell Starbucks at the price that you choose, the strike price, within a specified period of time. So, Starbucks stock price $73 and you buy a long put option with a strike price of 70. As Starbucks falls to $65 per share, here's what it's going to look like. So this means that the holder of a put option now has the right to sell Starbucks shares at the higher strike price of 70. So if Starbucks comes crashing down, you're perfectly fine with that because you get to sell it at 70 no matter what because you own that put option even though the market price declines and it goes down to 65. title: Options vs. Stocks: Which is Safer? (Risk Management Explained)
excerpt: The covered call is an option strategy basically where an investor holds a long-term position say you're holding a lot of apple or a lot of Google or Tesla whatever stock that you have you can sell a covered call option and that will give you income. let me show you a a roll so let's say I have this apple covered call right here all right so let's pretend that this is like Tesla right so if Tesla and it's about the same price which is cool as well let's say that Tesla goes up to like 182 or apple right in this example and you don't want to get rid of the stock at 182 and a half what you would do is you would simply roll this position now I love rolling because when you roll you can adjust a position you can either save money you can make more money and you can change your strike price so here let's say that Apple went up to 1822 I can just simply go to roll this position all right and then I would change it to a future date so instead of the current expiration which is basically really really soon for as I'm making this video you will go to a future expiration so let's say you know typically for me I like to run something that I call in my Discord Community I call it the dog strategy it typically Roll by 30 days so I'm going to move this out by 30 days now you will notice that I'll actually get paid to move this by 30 days so as you can see here I can easily move an option from 1825 to1 1885 so I'm going to move up by $25 which is really good that's that's quite a lot right I mean just one contract that's $250 but I have many contracts here so what this means is when I'm moving an option contract from 1822 to 185 I'm moving it up which gives me more upside which is amazing and here you can also see the net credit here is 92 okay that's because this option is worth more so the new option I'm rolling to because it's worth more I'm actually getting paid to roll I'm actually making money to move up this option that's exactly how you want to manage a position you want to slowly manage it like I'm not going to go from 182 and A2 here's a downside okay and this is not really a downside but let's say the stock moves from 177 to something huge right to like 200 okay if it goes to 200 then obviously I'm not going to be able to roll this for a reasonable amount you can see here there is a debit so you don't want to run this strategy on a crazy stock but at the same time if you run the color strategy on a crazy stock you still get the benefits that I mentioned in the video in the beginning I mentioned how you smooth that volatility so yes in theory you will have to pay a debit when you roll but in all it is a really good strategy you can still always Roll by a little bit so you don't have to roll from like you know a huge amount for me I like to roll by 2 and 1/2 5 maybe 10 so for example if I go to2 and2 you can see that I'm basically breaking even here I can move by a whole $10 this is a whole lot of money $10 times you know each option is 100 shares that's $1,000 okay here that's 68 contracts that's $68,000 so it is a really big difference here and I'm only paying $272 so you can basically move options quite a lot without high volatility or a low volatility can really impact your option pricing so if I go to April 19 right now and then I go to option that is not that far out of the money so let's say we go for the 900 call option okay you will notice here that the implied volatility is 58 which is pretty high if you have a high volatility that means that the option is going to be more expensive now it's kind of like a cash 22 because when an option is expensive that is likely an indication that the stock is moving up and down a lot that means there is opportunity to make a lot of money but at the same time a high implied volatility alerts investors and Traders that they need to have a lot more premium to compensate them for the risk so here you will see that the $900 call option is worth $58 that is a lot of money okay this is $5,800 now granted $5,800 is much better than owning 100 shares which would be $90,000 so you still get a really good discount here by buying a call option however if you're not correct on the direction then you can lose all this money right here and the high implied volatility is making this a lot more expensive if the implied volatility was lower then this premium would go down so you're basically making a bet do you think it's going to go up or down and the bet gets more expensive the higher the implied volatility however this is a trade-off because stocks with high imply volatility can go up a lot so you can still make a lot of money for example on Nvidia the stock has been going crazy so on Nvidia you can make a lot of money even if you are sort of correct on the direction and the implied volatility is very High because the stock has been going up like absolutely crazy so if I go to the 3-month Chart even if you were to spend a lot of money on a call option let's say back when it was at $492 even if you bought like a $550 call option that would be expensive it would probably be worth like $50 $50 or so right but the stock went from $492 all the way to like over $800 so if you would have paid $50 and it went to 800 you would have 800 minus 500 which is $300 you have a gain of $300 and you paid $50 to turn into $300 so you would have a 6X return by buying a call option on Nvidia or probably even a lot more than that if you would have just bought it a few months ago actually it would be a lot more than that because even a couple of months ago the implied volatility was a lot less so the premium on buying call options might have been like 25 so you would have had like a 12x return.

title: Wheel Strategy
excerpt: spy is very stable for that the wheel strategy is a very popular option trading strategy that involves selling covered calls and cash secured puts on a particular stock or ETF in this case spy the goal of the strategy is to generate income by collecting premiums from selling these options while also potentially acquiring shares of the underlying asset at a lower price to implement the wheel strategy on spy you would start by selling a cash secured put option on the ETF at a strike price that you would be comfortable owning the shares at

title: How Charlie Munger Actually Made Money with Options
excerpt: one instance involved monger's investment in the Walt Disney Company Disney faced some difficulties in the '90s and Munger saw this as an opportunity to enhance his returns using options instead of just holding Disney stock Monger used a covered call strategy he sold call options on his Disney shares allowing another investor the right to buy those shares at a specific price known as a strike price the covered call strategy provided Monger was several advantages first it generated additional income in the form of premium payments from selling the call options this income acted as a buffer particularly in periods of stagnant or slightly declining stock prices second Monga retained ownership of the underlying Disney shares benefiting from any potential upside in the stocks value by strategically implementing covered calls Monger effectively turned a passive stock investment into income generating asset this approach aligned with his emphasis on creating value from existing holdings while managing risk it's important to note that monger's option strategies were not about making aggressive bets but rather about optimizing returns with the confines of his circle of competence

title: How Charlie Munger Actually Made Money with Options
excerpt: Monger also invested heavily in Coca-Cola Monger having a long-standing investment in poke deployed options to enhance this yield on his investment having a long-standing in Coke he sold put options on Coca-Cola stock granting another investor the right to sell shares to him at a predat determined price this strategy allowed Monger to collect premiums while potentially acquiring more Coca-Cola shares at a discounted investment but these Investments underscore Monger strategic and deliberate use of options the goal was not speculation but rather the enhancement of returns and risk management within a value investing framework while these examples showcase Monger success with options it's essential to approach option trading with a deep understanding of the associated risks and to tailor strategies to individual investment goals

excerpt: for me I love doing selling strategies and after working at Goldman Sachs and after working at PNC Capital Advisors in Philadelphia after studying under a A Wharton Professor who is oftentimes on CNBC after talking to a financial advisor who manages NBA player money and pretty much dozens of people in between I've talked to a lot of professionals that either trade full-time as active full-time Traders which to be honest is one of the worst jobs in the world and I don't understand why it's so glorified people think that that job is amazing but in all reality I've actually never seen a full-time Trader even have hair in his head it seems like all those guys are super stressed and they're just by their computer which in my opinion is not a high quality or not a high standard of living I would never want to sit there by the computer and my personal belief is that the more you trade the worst results that you get I mean I've seen so many teachers like English teachers and just High School teachers outperform Wall Street professionals that honestly those Wall Street professionals went to Harvard or Yale they have economics degrees they have Finance degrees they have physics degrees which by the way Wall Street loves physics and math degrees more than finance and economics degrees and those people who have all this education all of this time spent on a really fancy degree with you know really good experience sure but in all honesty they still underperform someone who's putting in less work

title: $7,500/Month Selling Call Options For Passive Income EASY Quick Explanation
excerpt: for example let's say that you own 100 shares of Apple stock which is currently trading at $150 per share you sell a call option with a strike price of 160 receiving a premium of $8 per share then say over the following weeks Apple tanks down to 142 a stockholder would feel pretty disappointed and concerned about their investment they may experience a significant loss in their portfolio value of $8 per share the covered call investor who sold the call option with a strike price of 160 and received a premium of $8 per share would feel better in comparison to the person that just bought Apple stock in fact that person would make $8 the stock went down $8 so it would be a complete wash even though the stock has declined to 142 per share the covered call investor would have already collected the premium of $8 per share which lowers their cost basis to 142 per share essentially the covered call creates a big cushion against any downside risk
